This is an amazing example of how to actually analyze your mistakes in order to learn from them, thank you! There is another possible improvement in your thought process which is revealed at 04:45 - you got a signal from your intuition that there was something wrong but failed to pay attention to it because it was faint and easy to ignore. The relevant technique here is called "noticing confusion", which I've found incredibly useful to catch mistakes early and to find gaps and errors in my model of something in the world.

I often find myself in a similar situation, particularly regarding concepts that aren't in my field. I've invested a decent amount of time into trying to understand certain concepts in physics, for example, and it seems to me obvious that they are wrong, based on my current reasoning. Yet at the same time I am perfectly aware that these concepts are almost certainly correct, that if they aren't, it's extremely unlikely that my reasoning explains why, and that I'm just missing some aspect of the explanation. Of course I say this with a certain humility that I unfortunately have also learnt from experience. These days I try my best to discuss things without trying to position myself as someone who has authority on it ; I am just a learner whose only desire is to find the truth,
whether that means I was right to begin with or, more likely, I wasn't.

Holy shit this hits me hard!!! Those things explain exactly why I’m wrong when I’m wrong 😂 and also why I have anxiety 😬

1 & 2. When thinking/wanting to do something what’s the best thing to do now for the future I can easily fall into many logical fallacies and eventually in a paradox because I’m thinking too much in absolutes and at the same time considering multiple possible outcomes. I tend to cling to my way of seeing future outcomes that I can’t really know for sure but like I’m seeing them in general like that’s going to lead to more work to fix the wrong outcome that could’ve been avoided all along 😅

Although same time I know something might not go the way I think. Still
A) the past evidence points that I’ve usually been right in the majority of cases and I’ve got praises for been so thoughtful that others have end up saving time/resources etc

B) those are still possible outcomes, I might be right or wrong just like anyone else, since no one knows the future for sure until it happens (also the reason why I can’t relax until the time has passed and we all know how it played out. That’s how I get stuck in the paradox)

C) I have the right to prepare myself for any future outcome etc that I see coming (or try to prevent something from happening) even no one else agrees it’s something that’s going to happen (heavily leaning to the points A and B here and knowing what would happen if I end up been right, why I would mostly start any of this in the first place) and because something happens despite whether we do something about it or not so why not choose the better option? 😬

For me life just goes on even if the outcome I predicted doesn’t happen and that’s amazing and I would love things going well every time but that’s not my reality and my suggestions usually aren’t anything too complex but they would ensure or at least make it more likely that we all get the wanted outcome.

So I end up asking why would anyone disagree with me since the alternative could be anything from wasted time to someone dying 😂 yes I know that those two aren’t the same at all but in my head I just can’t comprehend why would anyone waste their time/resources etc when there is clearly a better way of handling things etc (and nothing pisses me off more than agreeing to go the wrong way just to end up in situation where I hear you were right/we should’ve listened to you 😡😡 happened way too often so now I’ll cling even more to my way of doing things etc than before)

3. 4. Story of my life 😂 I have adhd and I’m autistic (and more) so patience is not my strong game 😬 I just see resolution and can’t understand why others don’t and what’s taking them so long and with the experience that it’ll lead to them wanting to do things my way anyway so why couldn’t we just jump right there 😬 (still willing spend lot of time to prove them wrong but it’s annoying and I would gladly jump over that part)

5. And all of the above leads me to be overconfident in my reasoning and not give up easily 😬

But one question remains why am I so often right even when I use so many fallacies and cognitive biases in my thinking/speaking? 😅

Edit. Now that I’ve fallen in the rabbit hole of researching about fallacies and biases I’ve found an answer to my question and it goes as such “The conclusion of an argument may be true, even if the argument contains a fallacy. I disagree with Primer's analysis of their mistakes. First is the grey area comparison they make in point 1 and 2. In point 1 they talk about having to avoid both the appeal to authority fallacy and the fallacy fallacy. In point 2 they talk about the probability of being wrong vs Four decades of peer-reviewed research being wrong. My big disagreement here is that there is something wrong with being wrong. I believe that there is virtue in following every line of thinking to it's logical conclusion. To agree with Hamilton's rule because of authority and decades of research when your own analysis disagrees is a form of dishonesty and hypocracy.

(I agree 100% with point 3 so I'm going to skip over it. You should seek people that will disagree with you on the topic and people that have already formed their own opinions on the topic.)

Secondly he talks about impatience and about publishing his work too early. In itself that's understandable, regularly putting out content is commendable. The point where things start to seem like a mistake is with point 5 when you take into account his audience size, his reputation as an educator (and the great videos he's put out in the past), and the fact that his audience probably isn't made up of experts in the topic. After considering those factors puting out misinformation might seem like the worst possible thing you could do, but I don't think that this is the case. One is the idea of individual responsibility. Youtube watchers should not trust information from youtube channels. Not educators, nobody. Diversity of your sources of information, not "quality" of your sources should be the most important factor for watchers. Being honest is not only inherently valuable, but it will also give your audience a much needed peek into how reliable you actually are as a source. They might be harmed in the short term by not trust you when you tell the truth next time, but they will be more independent and better critical thinkers in the long term.

Thirdly with point 5 Primer discusses another grey area, underconfidence vs overconfidence. They say that not speaking up when you are correct is a problem with underconfidence and that there are even situations where speaking up when you are wrong will help you gain a better understanding, but they incorrectly assert that "publishing is not one of those situations." Choosing not to introduce a group of people to a new idea is just demeaning. If a large number of people are talking about something then the overall knowledge will improve. Experts joining the frey will get more experience talking to confrontational laymen and the laymen will learn how to think deeper about it. Primer seriously did prove wrong an incorrect conception of Hamilton's rule and hopefully encountering this disproof would make other communicators much more careful not to accidentally put bogus ideas into the heads of poor people like Primer. And as for Primer himself, what are the chances that real behavior ecologists like the mentioned Sally Le Page would reach out specifically BECAUSE of a published video like this?

I think a lot of people censor themselves a bit too much and are far too hard on themselves when they are wrong. In the pursuit of truth, one should not have to compromise in the slightist their intellectual virtue, their individuality, their work, their confidence, or their honesty.

I actually don't think that the problem of imposters appearing will be fixed by introducing sexual reproduction. It will just lead to the same outcome.
You need a more complex system to simulate Hamilton's rule. The problem lies inherently in the fact that imposters are unrecognizable. Try a system where the color of the beard is freely mutatable as the color encoding itself, and where the altruistic behavior itself is defined as altruistic towards color ranges on all RGB axes. Also, make the mutation probability for color and altruism itself mutatable. And finally, make the mutation function more complex and evolvable so that a link between altruism towards its OWN color can evolve dynamically that survives color changes. That should make for a more interesting model. It will probably make it so that altruistic behavior appears but gets destroyed once an imposter appears UNTIL a population arises that have a high mutation rate to its own color but evolved a mechanism where the altruism towards the own color is preserved over generations even when the color changes. Kind of like animals recognizes kin over smell.
All very interesting stuff. But it will probably work once you introduce more factors like that.

There's an important distinction between "Appeal to Authority" and "Fallacious Appeal to Authority". The former is not necessarily a logical fallacy while the latter absolutely is. People often confuse the two and think that relying on any authorities is therefore wrong and you have to become a expert on everything from scratch, this is often wrong and often dangerous. See anti-vaxers or flat-earthers as examples.

It's only a fallacious appeal to authority when you appeal/refer to some authority that doesn't have actual relevant experience/knowledge/authority on the subject at hand. Example: Lawyers are rightful authorities on the legal system, but not an authority on how your immune system works.

I didn't see the first video and evolutionary biology is not my master class, but:

Hamilton's rule, especially the "kin selection" part feels essentially flawed.
If rB>C, why is r causally linked to B? This seems to be a mere assumption respectively correlation... You could say that if the r-value becomes too high, altruism B might decline, but despite the r=0 and r=1 disasters, I fail to see any airtight causality.
Even if r has a temporal advantage, too much r will ultimately reduce the gene pool and wouldn't it be actually obstructive for a civilisation if the gene pool gets cut back no matter if r has an advantage?
Additionally we should define altruism again for this scenario. The kin selection might work for non-conscious choices in a bee colony, but even mammal experiments have shown that altruism is not tied to familial bonds.

"Kind of silly to think that I would have found a flaw...", the silly part would be the lack of doubt in your own conclusions. When you want to test your defense, you need to destroy them without remorse.

"To think that I would have found a flaw", that was also true for lots of people who managed to find actual flaws in decade old theorems. A lot of those only hold because we haven't devised a flaw that could break it, but the only way it could have no flaw is if they managed to prove that there can be no flaw, and that's fairly more complicated.

Proving there's no God is harder than disproving proof that says there is a God, but disproving those does not prove there is no God.

I'm a layperson on Hamiltons rule, but somewhat experienced in scientific habitus: While I totally respect, appreciate and endorse such videos, it is common in scientific literature to stand by your own conclusions one has made within the framework and with the methodology of ones own work/paper. Of course, this doesn't mean one shall adhere to confirmation bias but be open to looking for possible mistakes, listening to others scientific advice and to assess the own work compared to the current state of research in this field. This is what the discussion part of a paper is for.

The legitimate essence of a discussion chapter might be: "So, this is my conclusion. It differs from scientific consensus/prevailing opinion. I am aware of that. Still, I did my best to check if I thought or worked erroneously or were prone to biases. Please, dear scientific community, correct me, if I am wrong, or take my results into consideration for possible future leads."

I don't know about the whole "absolutes" issue. Saying it's unlikely that an entire body of literature is incorrect really depends on how that literature was established. If there was, for example, an initial, bogus finding that was simply repeatedly referenced as the go-to paper to cite when writing on the same topic, then you can see how a large body of work could be just as likely to be wrong as a single paper (because they are all basically just the same paper with a bit of garnishing). I don't think it's unreasonable to think you may have hit on an issue with a long-standing rule or finding, but it's probably wise to ask a whole bunch of people to check your work if you think that's the case ;)

I commend you for owning-up. That is a wise move. But, when the authority is a qualified expert on the topic under discussion, then it is not a fallacy to make an appeal to qualified authority. However, when in a argument someone cites your video as an appeal to authority on Hamilton's rule, then that is an appeal to unqualified authority fallacy. In most cases, it is wise to defer to the most qualified expert on any given subject in-which you are not an expert.

I've not seen the original video, so I can't say how wrong you were. But it sounds more like you modeled a different species to which hamilton's rule would not apply. So it sounds like a case that doesn't model human reproduction well, not one that is invalid.

Now that you've taken down the video, I cannot look at what you said, with the knowledge of what made you incorrect, to see what sort of criteria led to your assertions. Because I don't think you are giving yourself enough credit. It sounds like Hamilton's Rule should not apply universally to all organisms, and so even you being wrong would make a more complete picture of the whole space.

Because it sounds like the postulate, Hamilton's Rule applies to all organisms, suffers from some type 1 error. And while switching to Hamilton's rule never applies may create more Type2 error than type1 error was removed. The identification of what situations are likely to fall to type 1 error is still critically important.

Debating the boundaries between when rule A applies to when rule B is the better model describes 90% of the field of physics for the last 50 years.

This isn't directly related, but your metaphor relating overconfidence to walking through a minefield and knowing the mines are there and all the while acknowledging them but not properly addressing that they require methodical forethought really struck home for me with something I've been going through lately. Almost 2 years ago now I started dating someone and over time signs started coming up that this person just wasn't ready for a relationship and that it would be miserable for both of us. Heck, I WAS miserable the first time I noticed these issues, but I thought that I could handle it because I felt like I'd worked hard enough on who I was as a person to be the emotional support system for two. "I can handle this, I'm thoughtful and patient, it'll get better." Of course, things happened simultaneously that confirmed my bias towards my ego and further bolstered my belief that I could be enough for both of us. Essentially, something bad would happen and my mind would be screaming at me "break it off, break it off", but I'd tell myself "just wait it out, it'll blow over and things will get better." And the pattern formed, something bad would happen and I'd want to break up but I kept telling myself "no, it'll be fine, just wait it out, things will get better." Many times, things did seemingly get better, a lot of the time they were great! It just didn't last though, and those spans of bliss were much too far and few between. I honestly believe I'd have kept this up for years had they not had the compassion for themselves and me and finally broke it off after having accepted that they weren't ready for a relationship. Only now am I realizing I may not have been ready either. There were more things at play such as my impatience prior to our dating as I hadn't been in a relationship for quite a long time before then so it seemed like I was missing my one opportunity to find my person. Also, the struggle of "making things work" further confirmed my bias of hard work equating to success, and hard work can sometimes be painful so this pain felt like just a symptom of the hard work I was putting into the relationship. However, a romantic relationship shouldn't be painful, it'll have struggle no doubt, but it shouldn't be painful, at least not 2 years in, and certainly not right at the start. Anyway, I just wanted to share how I related to your video in case anyone else might have had a similar experience and could relate. Thanks for making this video, you really helped solidify a lesson I needed to learn. I'll do my best to apply this to other aspects of life as well (it feels pretty malleable), and now I'm gonna go read about fallacies and Bayesian thinking lol

The appeal to authority is not a fallacy when the person you cite is an authority, rather than having an authority. Example: The King says that by his royal authority, the moon is made of green cheese - Fallacy, the King is not an authority on astronomy. Galileo says that by his evidence gathered from watching stars, the Earth orbits around the Sun - Not a fallacy, Galileo is an actual authority, derived from his evidence. The Ghost Which Always Speaks The Truth says the moon is made of green cheese - Not a fallacy, the moon is made of green cheese. Most of us haven't played with supercolliders enough to not be taking particle physics by authority.

You should read up about inductive vs deductive reasoning when researching it speaks a lot to mistake 4. Deductive essentially says you take an existing theoretical framework and see if you can develop it or add to it in some way, you work from an already contrsuted solid knowledge base and see if theres anything else going on. Particularly useful for inexperienced researchers but also useful to very experienced researchers too.

Inductive basically is see what patterns emerge as you research (as you did with Hamilton's law). This is usually best left to those with extensive knowledge in their field and usually difficult for more inexperienced researchers to pull off, either come up with something brand new or disprove something completely (but like you said in point 2 when dealing in probabilities not impossible! And many inexperienced researchers have created knew knowledge like this, it is just a lot harder). Take a look and see what you think

I often use this exact process to understand something better: 1) come up with reasons why a statement/rule I'm learning seems wrong or flawed, 2) take this (very likely wrong) reasoning seriously and try to refine it into an argument against what I'm trying to learn, and ) try to defend the thing I'm trying to learn against that argument.
This way I get "both sides" of the argument, often get a good sense of what the limitations of the original statement are (although there are usually more frontiers than just the ones I thought of), and protect myself against conspiratorial thinking because it always reminds me how easy it is to fall for confirmation bias if you don't follow this process to the very end.
It's not fit for all types of studying since it can take way too long for many subjects, but it's something most people do to some degree and I think it's good to be conscious and rigorous about it.

I've seen a good number of these "apology" videos and yeah, it's good to recognize when you made a mistake, fix it, and also tell people how you made it so they don't fall in the same trap. Good on you, mate!

However, one common trait of these videos is that they get too, I guess you could call it "guilty". CGP Grey's commentary video on TEKOI is a good example of this. He makes it clear he's made a terrible, soul-rending, world-breaking mistake and he's a moron for missing all the obvious signs and a dunce for not putting in yet another month of effort to find and correct it. You can tell he's deeply disappointed in himself and he's going to completely upend his production routine so these kinds of things never happen again. And while it's good that he's trying to improve the quality of his research, I can't be the only one who thinks he's taking his mistake a little too seriously.

I think I know why Mr. Grey felt that way: it's because disappointment compounds. He saw he made an error, and he was disappointed in himself. He realized it was something really simple, and he was disappointed in himself. He looked back at all the times he could have caught it, and he was disappointed in himself. And he begins writing the apology video and thinking about that whole process again and again, and thus he was disappointed in himself. What started as a mere "I made a silly oopsie" turned into "I'm ashamed and I need to change everything so this never happens again", not because his error was actually that cataclysmic, but because he looked at it over and over and felt just a little worse each time. So when the apology video came out, he thought he made for the viewers, but in reality, he meant it for himself.

Mr. Primer, I'm happy to say your apology video is not very guilty. BUT. I want you to remember something the next time this happens (because it will):
1) It's okay. Everyone makes mistakes.
2) You will be more angry and disappointed at yourself than everyone else combined.
3) Learn from it. Apologize to everyone once. Apologize to yourself once. Then move on.

I can't remember the exact contents of your video on Hamilton's rule, but was it just about the maths of relatedness in asexual vs sexual populations, or with the concept of kin-selection in general (you mentioned high mutation rates)? I work in microbial evolution and there are examples of kin-recognition and kin-selection in asexual populations. From one perspective, even the concept of multicellularity itself is based on relatedness-mediated altruism, which for instances causes your skin cells to participate in the propagation of your gametes into the future. Their high relatedness is key here, which is visible when we contrast humans to the slime mold dictostelium, were potentially unrelated single cells sometimes aggregate to form a transient multicellular fruiting body. This phenomenon is susceptible to competing and cheating genotypes that try to end up in the spores (the cells that form the next generation) in disproportionate amounts. This suggests that high relatedness is essential in suppressing cheating to the extent that true obligate multicellularity can evolve. In us, this is effectively enforced by our germ/soma separation.

Anyway, looking forward to the video's that will delve deeper into this matter. Your evolution video's really helped me to get a visual intuition for selection in populations!

Just wanted to clarify something you mentioned in your video.

Appealing to authority is a fallacy where you mention one expert’s position and assert is as true. One expert may be wrong, so citing one expert’s opinion isn’t a strong argument.

Referencing a scientific consensus is not an appeal to authority. Many scientists agreeing on something means it’s likely the best explanation we currently have. If every person that’s an expert in the relevant field and study that field everyday agree on something, there’s probably legitimate reason to believe it is correct. It’s similar to the line of reasoning as to why you can’t make good conclusions from studies with small sample sizes.

For instance, saying climate change is caused by humans because 97% of scientists and 99% of climatologists agree that climate change is caused by human activity is not a fallacious argument. This is simply using facts to strengthen your argument, and this is a good, logical argument.

There is something you said that irritates me and I want to make it clear. The logical fallacy is actually appeal to unqualified authority, and that is an important distinction. Appeal to authority is an inductive argument which is basically "the expert says this, so it is probably true." The probably is a key thing since inductive arguments aren't black and white in validity or "strength" as it is refered to. The fallacy is when you use that argument, which can be strong if used properly, but the "expert" isn't actually an expert. For example, "my economist doesn't think that there will be a covid vaccine soon, so it is likey that there won't be a covid vaccine soon" commits the fallacy of appeal to unqualified authority since my economist doesn't really have any experience with that.

Appeal to authority can be strong and aren't a fallacy or an incorrect way of thinking, but since it is on the inductive side of logic, it has to be taken with a grain of salt.

The moral of this story is that just like the logical fallacy, listening to people who aren't qualified to be speaking can lead you astray. I know that I will now stay away from this channel since I can see how little effort is taken in fact checking. If he is going to make such a big claim that nobody else has made, I would hope he would do a lot of checking to make sure it was right, and then he would have discovered that it was not, or that he is not qualified to speak on this topic. On top of this, I hate that to fix it, he uses other big words and concepts that he only has a vague idea of.

I understand that it was a mistake and how he got there, but cgp grey's mistake was much less terrible and I understood how it could be made, but here, it was just too big for me to get over.

Just a note on appeal to authority: it’s actually appeal to false authority, and it actually occurs when you use a public/historical figure or expert in one thing to verify something completely unrelated. An example would be seeing an ad with a famous sports player that is about a cleaning product. They are trying to get you to buy the product by showing you people you respect and trust, though the reason you respect them as a person of authority doesn’t actually help to verify the claim being made because their expertise is completely unrelated. Essentially, appeal to false authority doesn’t apply when the person is an expert on the subject. Listening blindly to Michael Jordan for basketball advice isn’t appeal to false authority because he is a true authority. But listening to him about which cleaning product to buy because you like him for his basketball IS appeal to false authority.

Appeal to Authority can be a pain sometimes, because while it is a fallacy and experts aren't automatically right, trusting the experts is almost always a more accurate method of determining truth than relying on your own thinking if you aren't thoroughly informed and practiced on the subject.

We want to encourage people to think freely, but at the same time if one's conclusion differs from those of the experts, it's really really really likely that they've made a mistake. It's hard to get people to simultaneously think critically while also accepting that the experts are almost certainly going to know better.

Basically, appeal to authority is a fallacy, but carelessly dismissing authority is part of how we end up with COVID deniers.

A bit of a trend I've noticed with the educational videos I watch:

The video will have a statement to the form of "X is true". I'll think of an apparent counterexample pretty easily and leave a comment describing it and basically asking "what's going on". Someone (usually not the author) will leave a response to the effect of "you forgot that X is true" (even though my original comment was about demonstrating that X was false in a specific scenario) and often stating that X is a well-known result. The phrasing will usually cue me into an assumption that they and the author were making but which no-one stated. Turns out the actual well-known result is "if Y then X", and my counterexample was a scenario where Y was false. If I'm lucky, that leads into a discussion about what actually happens when Y is false and about what situations have Y being "close enough" to being true in order to get reasonably-accurate results from assuming Y and thus assuming X.

It reminds me of the pumping lemma, which is a well-known result in abstract computing which is notorious for people stating an incorrect version of it whenever they try to describe it informally. Naturally, I'm about to try to describe it informally :p

A deterministic finite automaton is an abstract machine which can be in one of many (but not infinitely-many) states. It starts in a specific state and transitions between states based on what letters you feed it. Those states are its only form of memory, so if it's in state X and you give it letter Y, it will transition to state Z -- no matter what. There are no "dead ends" except in the sense that a the machine may "transition" to the state that it was already in. That's what defines this kind of machine.

If you feed it enough letters, the machine will have definitely hit one of its states at least twice (there's finitely-many states, so it would "run out of options" if it were to "try" to avoid duplicate states.). This means that if you were to restart the machine and given the same letters, but you skip the letters in between the machine's two visits to that one state, the machine will end up in the same place at the end of your "sentence". Similarly, you can duplicate that phrase arbitrarily many times (next to the original phrase, not scattered throughout the sentence or inserted into the middle of the original) and create a sentence which again puts the state machine in the same state as your original sentence.

That threshold length will be different for each machine, but it will be at most the number of states that the machine has.

We're all on the internet and probably have seen an "internet argument/'debate'", but they usually take the form of one side trying to come up with a fallacy the other is committing and then declaring victory. It's fair that if an argument is composed of a fallacy it's conclusion is incorrect. However, people tend to take it as the conclusion is incorrect, which is incorrect.

It's a useful heuristic but it's also good to reinforce that it's just a heuristic.
